City doctors send OPDs in ICU.description: CHANDIGARH: Outdoor patient department (OPD) services were on Monday affected in all three major hospitals — PGIMER, Government Multi-specialty Hospital, Sector 16, and Government Medical College and Hospital, Sector 32 — as doctors called off work to express solidarity with their colleagues in Kolkata. Thousands of patients who reached these hospitals had to return home without check-up. The most-affected were those who had come from far-off places, especially to PGI OPDs. Hori Lal, a resident of Mandi Gobindgarh, Punjab, had come to PGI in the morning after taking a leave without pay from the mill where he works to show his wife who has been experiencing pain in her right hand. He reached at 10am and waited till 1pm before returning disappointed. “I had to spend Rs 700 to come here with my wife and daughter. But this time it was all for a waste. We will have to return next Monday now as the doctor only sits on that day. She has extreme pain in her hand and was hopeful of getting some relief today. We had thought the cause of pain would be known and medicine would be given for relief as we got the CT scan report along, but no one saw it,” he said. In the sectors 16 and 32 hospitals, OPDS were shut down at 8.30am, while PGI doctors had announced on Sunday that they would suspend work in OPDs. In all three hospitals, especially in PGI, the faculty attended to patients in OPDs. In PGI, a contingency plan was devised to ensure functioning of the institute to the maximum extent possible. The OPD services were curtailed by reducing the registration timings by two hours. The OPD and diagnostic services were run by faculty, sponsored residents, foreign national residents and technical staff. As many as 3,596 patients were registered in the OPD on Monday, while 23 surgeries were performed till 5pm. All the emergency services, including labour room services, and intensive care units, functioned in a routine manner as these services were exempted from strike. Dr Jagat Ram, director, PGI, called a meeting of heads of departments on Sunday at 8 am to discuss the issue and prepare a contingency plan. Accordingly, a contingency plan was drafted and distributed to all heads of departments on Sunday itself. Dr BS Chavan, director, GMCH, said, “Though doctors called a shutdown, our faculty worked hard and covered 1,500 patients in the OPDs on Monday. They were on night duty as well. If the strike continues, our faculty will be at work.” In the protest on Monday, the doctors of three hospitals were joined in by members of Indian Medical Association (IMA), Chandigarh, Mohali and Panchkula units, which too had called for a strike for 24 hours till Tuesday. Doctors from different institutes joined the protest march in the evening. Dr Uttam Thakur, president, Association of Resident Doctors, PGI, said, “There is a need to enact laws in the entire country for safety of the doctors. Central security Act needs to be implemented in the whole of the country.” He said that if the demands were not, then they might even suspend emergency services, but added it would be the last resort. Spend more on health: PGI doctorDr Siddharth Jain, senior resident, rheumatology, PGI, said, “There is lack of understanding between patients and doctors and this is because of the lack of facilities. Public sentiments increase because of the delay in getting services as either there is shortage of doctors or that of hospitals.” “There is a need to increase the money being spent on health in the country, which at present does not match with the standards of WHO. We need to strengthen the infrastructure. All the doctors joining in for the cause shows the severity of the situation and need for the government to act fast,” he said. Tejashwi Yadav.description: PATNA/ BHAGALPUR: RJD chief Lalu Prasad’s younger son and leader of opposition in Bihar legislative assembly Tejashwi Prasad Yadav kicked off the Lok Sabha election campaign on Monday by addressing public meetings at Gaya, Banka and Bhagalpur in support of the Mahagathbandhan candidates. Close aides of Tejashwi said he is expected to address around 200 election meetings across the state over the next two months. “Tejashwi is the face of RJD and the star campaigner of Mahagathbandhan. He will be canvassing for candidates of all the Mahagathbandhan constituents — RJD, Congress, RLSP, HAM(S) and VIP. Thus, he will be addressing three to four election meetings every day,” Tejashwi’s political adviser Sanjay Yadav told TOI on Monday. Canvassing for RJD candidate Shailesh Kumar alias Bulo Mandal from Bhagalpur, Tejashwi came down heavily on NDA governments at the Centre and in state. He accused PM Narendra Modi of making false promises and propaganda to win the 2014 general election. “It won’t be repeated in the ensuing Lok Sabha elections,” Tejashwi said while raising questions about employment scenario and issues of Vijay Malaya, Nirav Modi, Mehul Chowksi and others who fled the country after swindling money from banks in India. Criticizing Nitish for snapping ties with RJD in 2017, Tejashwi said there was acute shortage of fertilizers, while the health services were also in a poor state. He accused deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi of protecting those involved in the multi-crore Srijan scam in Bhagalpur and some other districts. Urging the audience to vote for the RJD candidate, Tejashwi said the Bhagalpur voters had showed a mirror to Modi by voting for RJD in 2014. “They should do the same this election as the NDA government stands exposed,” he said. Political observers feel Tejashwi has become a good orator, especially after coming out of power in July 2017 when CM Nitish Kumar snapped ties with RJD-led Mahagathbandhan and rejoined BJP-led NDA. “Though not as good as his father in terms of having a rustic touch, Tejashwi is a good orator in terms of eloquence,” said DM Diwakar, political observer and professor at AN Sinha Institute of Social Studies. Arvind Kejriwal.description: VISAKHAPATNAM: Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Monday said that Congress President Rahul Gandhi has refused to forge an alliance with the AAP for the Lok Sabha polls in the national capital. Full coverage: Lok Sabha electionsTalking to reporters at the airport here, the AAP leader said he had met Gandhi recently and the Congress leader had refused to “join hands with the AAP”. Asked about Congress' Delhi unit president Sheila Dikshit's remarks that Kejriwal never approached her for an alliance, the chief minister said, “We have met Rahul Gandhi. Dikshit is not that important leader.” Kejriwal has been urging the Congress to stitch an alliance in Delhi for the Lok Sabha polls to keep the BJP away from power. Leaders in the Delhi unit of the Congress were divided over the issue of alliance with Dikshit and her three working presidents opposing it, party sources had said. A top source in the party had recently said that chances of alliance were "slim" considering its long term repercussions in Delhi. "The biggest question is how will Congress face the AAP in Assembly elections due in 2020 after the tie up. Also, the party does not gain much politically as it is being offered only 2-3 seats by Kejriwal," the source had said. Congress had drawn a blank in the 2014 parliamentary elections in Delhi. The talk of alliance was fuelled by the fact that the Congress and AAP had jointly polled more votes than the BJP that had walked away with all the seven seats in the national capital. Delhi has 7 Lok Sabha seats and it will go to polls on May 12. Repudiating accident claim proves costly.description: CHANDIGARH: The district consumer disputes redressal forum has directed United India Insurance Company Limited to pay Rs 35,000 for repudiating the claim of a Manimajra resident. They were also directed to pay the claim amount of Rs 48,100 to the complainant. Baaj Mohamad had stated in his complaint that on November 20, 2017, his insured tipper overturned in Phase 3, Mohali, while unloading material from the vehicle. In the process, factory-fitted hydraulic system of the tipper got severely damaged. Following this, the insurance firm was intimated about the loss/ damage to the vehicle. Upon this, a surveyor was appointed by the company to assess the extent of loss/ damage caused to the insured vehicle. The surveyor visited the complainant on November 24, 2017, and gave a go ahead to get the vehicle repaired from the market and told Baaj to get a second-hand hydraulic system fitted for which he would be fully reimbursed by the insurer. The complainant acted accordingly and the repairs incurred a sum of Rs 1.53 lakh, including towing charges to the tune of Rs 8,000. In the meantime, another surveyor appointed by the company visited the complainant and took photographs of the damaged parts of the vehicle and of the insured tipper post repair. Besides collecting a copy of the insurance policy, the surveyor promised full reimbursement against the amount spent. However, on January 4, 2018, the insurer rejected the claim. In its reply, the insurance firm stated that the claim was rightly repudiated as the loss caused to the vehicle was not covered under IMT 47 and 52. The forum after hearing both the parties observed, “If a vehicle is overturned and damaged, that would be a part of accident and when the accident is covered under the terms and conditions of the policy, overturning could not be excluded from that. If it was to be excluded, there should have been specific mention of the same in the cover note/ policy. In absence of such a mention, the insurance company cannot say that since no premium was paid for overturning, the risk of overturning was not covered.” It was further stated that the insurer or its agents were under obligation to disclose the extra premium for overturning and if the same was not paid, overturning would not be covered. But from the record, it does not appear that this obligation was discharged by the agents of the insurance company and thus the firm cannot claim the benefit of the overturning exclusion clause. “In view of the above findings, we are of the concerted opinion that the repudiation of claim of the complainant is wholly unjustified and amounts to deficiency in service on the part of the company, which certainly has caused immense, mental and physical harassment to the complainant,” the forum observed. They were then directed to pay up. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Chandigarh: BTech registration at PEC on.description: CHANDIGARH: Admission to Punjab Engineering College (deemed to be university) is now open and registration can be done till June 23. PEC is an institution of high repute and stands 73rd in the All India Ranking 2018 by the National Institutional Ranking Framework (NIRF). The institute, situated in Sector 12, Chandigarh, has also started PhD programmes in the disciplines of engineering, science, management, humanities and social sciences. Admission to its undergraduate and postgraduate programmes is done through national level examinations such as JEE (Main) and GATE. The 146-acre sprawling campus is divided into various functional zones like hostels, institute building, new academic block, administrative block, technology block, residential complex for faculty and staff and a mini market. In addition to lecture theatres, tutorial rooms, committee rooms, seminar rooms, board room, senate hall and drawing halls, the institute has an auditorium, open-air theatre, library and computer centre, reading rooms, workshops and well-equipped laboratories. The campus is under CCTV surveillance to ensure safety of students. Wi-Fi facility is provided only in the academic area. The college has a serene environment with varied foliage. It has palatial playgrounds, tennis courts, squash courts, swimming pool, gymnasium, student club and technical society area. The institute provides banking facilities to students through nationally connected ATMs and computerized post office. There are nine academic departments and two centres of excellence. The faculty of academic departments and centres is highly qualified. They make sure that the students are taught in a way that makes them have an edge over their peers. The college library covers an area of 27000 sq ft having two interlinked buildings — Old block and New block. It is fully air-conditioned, computerized with Libsys software and can accommodate around 382 students. The Wi-Fi enabled library is organized into various sections like circular section, periodical section, reference section, multimedia section, newspaper/ magazine section, technical section, book bank (general and book bank SC/ST), binding section, which are manned by professionally qualified staff. There is a special room on the ground floor for the library users who are physically challenged. The college library has a total number of 1,20,500 books, more than 3,000 e-journals, more than 3800 e-books and around 2500 e-resources in the form of CDs, DVDs, video cassettes. It also provides access to anti-plagiarism software. There is RFID system for efficient tracking of books. A self-services station has also been installed to facilitate users with self-issue/ return of documents. Theft detection pedestals have been installed at the entrance and exit gates of the library to check the movement of unissued books outside the library. Hostel accommodation is provided to the students as per the availability of rooms. The hostel can accommodate around 1,240 college inmates including boys and girls. Hostel rooms are spacious and fully furnished. Common rooms are fully air-conditioned for recreational facilities. There is provision of newspapers and magazines, common television set, equipment for indoor/outdoor games. Each hostel has a separate mess that provides nutritious vegetarian food. 'Punjab govt to bear treatment expenses.description: BATHINDA: Punjab minister Charanjit Singh Channi on Tuesday met the woman who was mercilessly beaten up last week by six persons and announced that the state government will bear the expenses incurred on her treatment. He visited the victim at Guru Gobind Singh Medical College in Faridkot. Channi also announced the state government will act tough against the accused persons. He reiterated that the Punjab government is duty bound to provide free, transparent and fearless environment to every section of the society and said there will be no injustice against anyone. Two more held in Rs 1 crore Karnal robbe.description: KARNAL: The police have arrested two more accused in connection with Rs 1-crore robbery in the house of automobile dealer Rahul Rao in Karnal on May 21. They also recovered 1.185 kg gold jewellery, 2 kg silver jewellery, one mobile phone and Rs 5 lakh cash looted from the victim from the possession of the accused. With this recovery, the police claim that remaining half of the robbed valuables have been recovered. They had recovered the half of the robbed valuables from two accused nabbed earlier. Those arrested were identified as Surendra alias Pawan, the main accused, and Ranjeet, both residents of Gogri village in Bihar. Acting on a tip-off, CIA-1 in-charge Deepender Rana-led team arrested the duo from Kundli border in Sonipat district, said deputy superintendent of police (DSP) Virendra Saini. DSP Saini said the accused were taken on a three-day police remand, during which the police recovered the looted valuables. On May 21, three miscreants in connivance with the servant of the house had looted cash and jewellery worth over Rs 1 crore after taking Jyoti Rao, daughter-in-law of Rahul Rao, her kids and their maid hostage. The servant had been hired through a Delhi-based agency only three-four days before the incident. With the arrest of these two remaining accused, all the looted valuables have been recovered. Satta Market.description: BHOPAL: This assembly  is turning out to be a nail-biter. The Bhopal satta bazaar that gave BJP a good chance three weeks ago is suddenly abuzz about Congress’ prospects. As per the bookies, till about a month ago, if a person placed a bet of Rs 10,000 on BJP, he would get Rs 11,000 if the party returned to power. And anyone who bet Rs 4,400 on Congress would get Rs 10,000 if the opposition wins. This week, bookies say, they are taking bets on number of seats and not on who would form the government. “In case no party gets absolute majority, or if the scoreline is too close,” explained a bookie. “We do not want to say which party will form the government. The bets are open. The satta market is running good this poll season, as it is a thrilling contest,” he added. Bookies told TOI that satta trends may not reflect the actual situation on the ground, but the market is accepting bets on 116-plus seats for Congress and 102 or more for ruling BJP. “Anyone who bets successfully on BJP or Congress will double his money,” a bookie said, adding that this trend may change just as suddenly in the next few days as campaigning gets more intense. The same bookie had told TOI around a month ago that rates may vary once candidates are finalised by the parties, “but we expect the trend to remain the same”. The satta market runs into crores in every election. Bets are placed not just over phone, but also on websites and apps, leaving almost no room for police to track down bookies and those placing bets. Probably, this is why no gang has been busted in the state so far for running an election betting racket. At least two cases of betting are registered daily in Bhopal, but the people pulling the strings of the racket in poll season are yet to be caught. Police officers say it is getting increasingly difficult to nab such gangs because they are constantly on the move. “Online betting can be operated even from a moving car, a café or any public place anywhere in the country. Those running the betting in Bhopal may be sitting anywhere on the globe,” said an officer. SP-south Rahul Kumar Lodha said a special campaign is being run against criminals involved in gambling and betting ahead of elections. “These criminals are made to sign bonds to prevent them from committing such crimes in the future. Raids are being conducted on specific tips. A list of habitual offenders is being prepared by police stations to curb such illegal activities,” he said. ASP-crime Rashmi Mishra said the crime branch has activated its network of informers prior to elections to keep an eye on betting. “It is difficult to crack online betting and gambling rackets, but police take action against criminals on specific inputs. For instance, we were tipped off on Monday night about a betting den in Kolar. It was raided but no such activity was found,” Mishra said, adding that the cyber cell is constantly on the lookout for websites and mobile apps used by betting rackets. Medical services take a hit in Mohali.description: MOHALI: Medical services were hit in Mohali on Monday as the doctors took part in the nationwide protest to condemn the alleged attack on two junior doctors in West Bengal. Out patient departments (OPDs) of all private and government hospitals were closed. Patients were seen sitting in waiting halls to get medical aids, hoping the doctors might come back after calling off the strike. However, the protesting doctors with black ribbons pinned on their shoulders claimed only OPDs were closed and all essential services, including rounds by doctors in wards, were not affected. The protesting doctors also presented a memorandum to health minister Balbir Singh Sidhu demanding protection. Dr Sanjeet Singh Sodhi, president, Indian Medical Association (IMA), Mohali, said there have been a number of incidents in the recent years of doctors already working under stressful conditions being assaulted by patients or their relatives. “The recent incident in West Bengal is appalling to say the least. Doctors must get better security,” he said. Sidhu assured the protesting doctors that if any such incident occurs in Punjab, there would be immediate registration of an FIR against the accused. Dr Viren Dhankhar, secretary, IMA, Mohali, stated that a surgeon would never be able to give his best in high-risk cases if he has the fear of violence in his mind. This will ultimately be detrimental to the health of the patient, he said. According to Dr Charandeep Singh, there are various avenues for complaints against negligence but taking law into one’s own hands is not acceptable. Dr Ashwani Kansal said IMA, Mohali, has full sympathies for the patients but has no option other than to cease OPD and non-essential medical work for the day to protest the unruly behaviour of the patients. Dr P Singh appealed to the West Bengal and the central government to take steps toward imparting justice to the assaulted doctors and prevent any violent incident in the future. 12 of 13 Punjab MPs take oath in Punjabi.description: JALANDHAR: Twelve out of the 13 MPs from Punjab took their oath as members of the 17th Lok Sabha in Punjabi this time, barring Gurdaspur MP Sunny Deol. It is probably the first instance in recent times that MPs from all parties — Congress, Shiromani Akali Dal, BJP and Aam Aadmi Party — preferred to take oath in the state language. Only Deol took his oath in English. While two Union ministers Harsimrat Kaur Badal and Som Parkash had taken their oath in Punjabi on Monday, 10 other MPs followed suit on Tuesday. Linguistic diversity was the flavour of the oath-taking this time as MPs from across India predominantly took oath in their mother tongue, be it Dogri, Kannada or Konkani. Gurdaspur MP Sunny Deol takes the oath of office in EnglishOver a fornight before on May 30, Harsimrat and Som Parkash had taken their ministerial oath in English, but they were trolled by Punjabi netizens. Second-time Jalandhar MP Chaudhary Santokh Singh said it was for the first time that 12 out of 13 MPs had taken oath in Punjabi. Former MP Prem Singh Chandumajra, who was elected to Lok Sabha thrice, said it was after quite some time that such a large number of MPs from Punjab had taken oath in Punjabit. "It was probably in 1977 that all Punjab MPs, barring one, had taken oath in Punjabi," he said. Three-time MP Ravneet Bittu also said that the number this time was maximum. The symbolism of MPs across parties and from diverse communities taking their oath in Punjabi in the Parliament assumes significance for Punjab, where language was made the reason of communal rift in 1950s and 60s and the state witnessed a bitter campaign against Punjabi language. While SAD president Sukhbir Singh Badal concluded his oath with Sikh greeting “Waheguru Ji ka Khalsa, Waheguru Ji Ki Fateh”, Sanguru MP Bhagwant Mann concluded with “Inqalab Zindabad”. Sukhbir using the Sikh salutation is being seen as an attempt to assert the Panthic identity of the Akali Dal as the party trying hard to recover its lost base. Anandpur Sahib MP Manish Tewari, who is usually seen speaking in English, also took his oath in Punjabi. His father late Prof V N Tewari, who was a member of Rajya Sabha, was a prominent scholar of Punjabi literature. The move was also lauded by Punjabi netizens. “It will not only help in getting Punjabi language better recognition at the national level, but will also help to strengthen the spirit of Punjabiyat and Punjabi identity. The MPs should now make their speeches also in Punjabi in Parliament,” said Satnam Singh Manak, president of Punjabi Jagriti Manch, which takes out an annual Punjabi march on international Language Day. 6 people die on Mohali roads every week,.description: MOHALI: As many as six people lose their lives every week in road accidents in Mohali — the second highest fatality rate in Punjab — according to a government study on road safety analysis and identification of accident-prone areas. The office of traffic adviser, Punjab, took note of accidents from 2016 to 2018 in the study that found Rupnagar had the highest death rate out of the 22 districts in the state. The report was tabled in a meeting chaired by senior superintendent of police (SSP) to review traffic-related problems in the district. According to the report, 310 people died in 2017 and 290 in 2016 in Mohali. The number of deaths in 2018 was 297. The study found that the months of February, March, April, October and December were relatively more dangerous as regard to fatal accidents. The report was divided into three main aspects — dealing with general trends of accidents over the past three years along with its various analysis; dealing with the availability of resources within the state and in Mohali along with corresponding road accidents and highway patrol vehicle deployment. A detailed police station wise analysis revealed that Lalru, Derabassi and Zirakpur were the three police stations out of 14 in which more than 47% deaths were reported. All are on Ambala-Zirakpur national highway. Sohana and Kharar sadar police came next. In Lalru, 52 people lost their lives in 2017 followed by 43 in Derabassi, 40 in Zirakpur and 33 in Sohana in 2017. The report said 135 people died on the stretch between Zirakpur and Jharmari in 2017. Flaws detected in airport road designPunjab traffic adviser Navdeep Asija had also conducted a three-dimensional (3D) safety audit using drones to investigate the geometric design of three blind spots on the airport road in Mohali. The report revealed major flaws in design and engineering, proving that the road is not pedestrian and cyclist-friendly. The 3D audit was conducted on road crossings near Sohana gurdwara, IISER intersection and Sector 66-67 light point intersections. The report suggested that construction of modern roundabouts on these strategic locations could prove efficient and safer. Asija said, “We have conducted 3D study of geometric design of three blind spots on the airport road in Mohali using drones and have observed major flaws in design which causes accidents and make airport road unsafe for people. The road is not safe for pedestrians and cyclists as they are the majority of accident victims. So, we have laid special design emphasis for safety of pedestrians and cyclists while suggesting improvements. None of the traffic lights on these junctions is as per the traffic volume.” He said the office conducted the drone survey last month and on the basis of its findings prepared a report on March 12. It has been submitted to the inspector general, traffic, and would be forwarded to Greater Mohali Area Development Authority (GMADA) for corrective action. Om Birla.description: NEW DELHI: The BJP's surprise pick — Om Birla — is all set to become the next Lok Sabha Speaker after his candidature on Tuesday was backed by all NDA allies as also by the YSR Congress Party, the Biju Janata Dal and key opposition parties, including the Congress. A notice was given to the Lok Sabha Secretariat by the BJP, proposing the name of Birla, a two-time MP from Kota-Bundi seat in Rajasthan, for the Speaker's post and bringing a motion for his election, which will be held on Wednesday. As per sources, Prime Minister Narendra Modi proposed 57-year-old Birla's name for the post. The Rajasthan leader is considered to be close to both Modi and BJP president Amit Shah. 10 parties extend support to Om Birla's candidature for Lok Sabha speaker: Prahlad JoshiBirla's surprise nomination is seen by many in the BJP as a message from the top leadership that the party will promote leaders who keep a low-profile and work at the ground-level. BJD, YSRCP, JDU, Shiv Sena, Akali Dal, National People's Party, Mizo National Front, Lok Janshakti Party, AIADMK and Apna Dal have given the notice to support Birla's candidature for the Speaker's post, parliamentary affairs minister Pralhad Joshi told reporters. Later, Congress leader Adhir Ranjan Chowdhury said the party and the UPA allies have also decided to support the candidature of Birla as the Speaker. Chowdhury also said the Congress has already moved a motion supporting the ruling party candidate. The decision to support Birla's nomination was taken at a meeting of the UPA allies, where the leaders also discussed the opposition strategy during Parliament session. Birla won his first Lok Sabha election in 2014 and was re-elected from Rajasthan's Kota-Bundi seat. He defeated Congress's Ramnaraian Meena with a margin of over 2.5 lakh votes in the recently concluded general election. He has also been elected to Rajasthan assembly for three consecutive terms in 2003, 2008 and 2013. Birla will succeed eight-term MP Sumitra Mahajan as the Speaker, a post traditionally held by senior MPs. However, this will not be for the first time a relative newcomer will hold the position. In 1996, TDP leader G M C Balayogi was also a two-time MP when he was elected as the LS Speaker and after his death in a helicopter crash in 2002, Shiv Sena leader and the first-time MP Manohar Joshi was appointed to the position. Shiv Sena List 2019.description: MUMBAI: Shiv Sena has come up with it's first list of 21 candidates, out of 23 to contest in Lok Sabha polls in Maharashtra. Except Osmanabad, 17 sitting Sena MP's are part of the list, includes Mumbai, Thane, Kalyan, Raigad. Following complaints received by local functionaries from Osmanabad, the party has denied ticket to sitting MP Ravindra Gaikwad. Gaikwad, who had allegedly hit an Air India staffer with his slipper because he was refused a business class seat in March 2017. Maharashtra: Track here Lok Sabha elections' full coverageSena has kept two seats, Palghar and Satara, on hold, likely to announce on Sunday. Late Chintaman Wanga, former BJP MP's son Shrinivas likely to contest from Palghar on Sena ticket whereas former NCP legislator Narendra Patil may might contest as Sena candidate from Satara. Patil met Shiv Sena president Uddhav Thackeray on Friday at Matoshree. Other candidates are: South Mumbai: Arvind Sawant; South Central Mumbai: Rahul Shewale; Mumbai North West: Gajanan Kirtikar; Kalyan: Shrikant Shinde; Raigad: union minister Anant Gite; Osmanabad: Omraje Nimbalkar, Ratnagiri-Sindhudurg: Vinayak Raut; Kolhapur-Sanjay Mandlik; Hatkanangle: Dhairyasheel Mane; Nashik: Hemant Godse; Shirdi: Sadashiv Lokhande; Shirur: Shivajirao Adhalrao Patil; Aurangabad: Chandrakant Khaire; Yavatmal Washim: Bhawana Gawli; Buldana: Prataprao Jadhav; Ramtek: Kripal Tumane; Amrawati-Anandrao Adsul, Parbhani: Sanjay Jadhav; Maval: Shrirang Barne; Hingoli: Hemant Patil. Enact law to curb violence against docto.description: CHANDIGARH: Members of the Indian Medical Association (IMA), Chandigarh, its Mohali unit and resident doctors of Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH), Sector 32, held a meeting at the Dr P N Chuttani Memorial IMA Complex, Sector 35, on Monday. Dr Hardeep S Santokh, secretary, IMA, Chandigarh, said the call for withdrawal of non-essential services was necessary as the West Bengal government was adamant in its approach. The IMA said the 24-hour shutdown was just a glimpse of what could follow if the issues were not addressed. Dr Sushil Gupta, former president, IMA, Chandigarh, said more than 1,000 senior doctors had resigned from government hospitals owing to the “inhumane treatment” meted out to their junior colleagues. He said the IMA has a zero tolerance policy against violence on doctors and healthcare establishments and a Central Prevention of Violence against Medicare Services persons and Establishment Act has been a long pending demand of the association. Dr Neeraj Kumar, former president, IMA, Chandigarh, said that this law should be stringent enough to act as a deterrent. The IMA on Monday also submitted a memorandum of their demands, including immediate adoption of an existent state law for prevention of violence against doctors and creation of a hotline with a quick response team headed by a senior police official to pre-empt such incidents to the senior administrative officers of the city.
